 Yes, Q u e e r as folk caused a huge stir when it was first aired in the UK in 1999- I remember the usual throthing at the mouth response from papers like the Daily Mail etc. about how Channel 4 was corrupting us all blah blah...
 
 No doubt much of that was to do with the fact the show was about gay men (although Brookside's famous lesbian kiss also kicked up a stir- particularly in relation to the relatively early time the show was aired).
 
 One portrayal of a gay (in this case gay women) relationship in TV that I always thought was well done was in the BBC Police drama Between the Lines where the main female character was gay. Firstly it dealt with the hostility she faced from some collegues when she "outed" and secondly because it dealt with the stresses a high powered career puts on a relationship- this was clever as it put a story that is not uniquely to do with a gay relationshop in that context, making a point of not just having the characters being gay just to have specific storylines relating to that. This series ran between 1992 and 1994.
 
 Although slightly OT, one thing that I find interesting is the portrayal of same sex desire in advertising. Over the last few years there has been a fair amount of imagery that features 2 women posed in a way as to indicate desire for one another. No doubt this appeals to most of the men amongst us emoticon_xangel but I find it difficult to imagine the same sort of imagery but using men instead.
